Comments_List:
quantum mechanics, 
dirac notation,
p chem of electronic, vib, rot spec
NMR spec

Overall, it was a really helpful course for grad students, because it taught most of the basic spectroscopy theories in great mathematical detail, and yet managed to cover a large number of topics (whose basics ideally would have been covered in undergrad courses) in an organised fashion.
I learned so much, and really appreciate how in depth the class went into such interesting topics.
A mathematical, and sometimes physical, understanding of quantum chemistry.
The course gave me a good introduction into quantum chemistry, matrix algebra, and spectroscopy.
This course provided a strong background in quantum mechanics as it pertains to spectroscopy. The course covered a large amount of useful material over the semester.
I gained a much firmer foundation on quantum mechanics and its applications to spectroscopy than I had coming in.

Kurt sometimes went toooooo fast!!
But I loved the anecdotes and when he talks about how the things he taught is class is implemented in research both in the past and in present days

Strengths: Organised, covered a wide range of topics efficiently in a semester
Weaknesses: The NMR portion could have been taught better

Strengths include weekly psets that are grounded in applications of the science, the professor's familiarity with the material, and the weekly discussion section. I think it could be improved with more explicit reading material. While I appreciate the professor's notes, I think clear textbook readings would help flesh out the conceptual framework.

Overall, the course was very well-organized and useful. I liked that all of the notes were available both in printed and digital form. I also felt that the homework assignments were useful and relevant. One suggestion for improvement would be to not include topics from the Monday lecture on the homework assignments due Tuesday. I had a busy Monday schedule, and it was difficult to find time to complete these assignments on Monday night.

Strengths:
The organization of this course was done very well with students knowing what to expect and the level of work appropriate for being accomplished by the given due date, especially as mid term season came around.

Weaknesses:
Overall, there is very little to criticize with this course. Some of the lecture notes could do with an extra example or a more explained one, but this was really a very good course that was taught well.
It really depends on their interest and what they want to do for research since it'll affect their involvement. However, I think this is a very essential course for chemistry major
Yes. I think it helped immensely with developing my understanding of quantum chemistry.

Yes and no. If the student is a fast learner, I would recommend the course. If the student often requires assistance from the professor to learn, then no. If a different professor were to teach the course, I would likely recommend it.

I would recommend this course to any student interested in quantum mechanics or spectroscopy. The course covers a lot of useful material in a relatively short time. It also helps to improve one's mathematical skills.
Yes, as above mentioned, a lot was learned from this course.
